Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Quantitative Principles Governing the Cellular Metabolic Network

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Cellular metabolism is a universal biological process, in which incoming nutrients are converted by cells into the energy and chemical building blocks that they need to survive and grow. It is carried out by a network of about 1000 interconnected chemical reactions. These reactions have been carefully mapped over the past century and have been found to be very similar across species ranging from bacteria to humans. With relatively complete maps of the metabolic network now in hand, there is the opportunity to begin to analyze the quantitative behavior of the entire system. Such analysis requires better tools for measuring the full spectrum of the system's components. The present research will develop methods for quantitating intracellular metabolite concentrations and fluxes using liquid chromatography - tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS), a state-of-the-art measurement technique. LC-MS/MS takes complex samples and separates them based on the individual components' physical properties and molecular weights, thereby allowing each component to be isolated and measured. The new measurement capabilities will be applied to determine the complete response of the unicellular model organisms Escherichia coli and Saccharomyces cerevisiae to environmental perturbations such as providing and removing fundamental nutrients. The metabolite concentration and flux responses will be used to guide the development of dynamic models of cellular metabolism. These models will begin to enable effective computational simulation of metabolic activity and its regulation. The broader impacts of this project include development of methods of probing metabolism of use to a wide range of investigators and identification of governing metabolic principles applicable also to bioengineering and mammalian biology. This research should lay the basic science groundwork to advance a diversity of applications, such as use of microorganisms to make alternative fuels and design of drugs to treat metabolic diseases like diabetes.

The educational portion of the project aims to fill the unmet niche of providing a quantitative introduction to biochemistry for early stage undergraduates. It involves developing a new curriculum that integrates, around a central focus in metabolism, the teaching of biochemistry, organic chemistry, genetics, and elementary differential equations. The curriculum will include three core components: lectures, a textbook, and interactive computer-based exercises that walk students through the development of basic metabolic models. The effectiveness of the web-based exercises and lectures will be tested and refined through their classroom application, prior to codifying the material into a formal text and CD-ROM for students nationwide. The broader impact of this education effort will include training a diverse new generation of systems biology scientists. This will be achieved in two ways: by involving undergraduate and graduate students including underrepresented minorities in all stages of the research program and by developing a curriculum that engages undergraduates (at Princeton and nationwide) in quantitative biology early in their careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metabolism is the process of taking in nutrients and converting them into usable energy, building blocks of functional biological molecules, and waste. This process is carried out via a set of roughly 1000 enzyme-catalyzed chemical reactions, which are a universal and essential feature of all living organisms. While most of metabolic reactions and the associated enzymes are known, the ways in which they are controlled are not thoroughly understood. Better understanding is essential for enabling more effective metabolic engineering (e.g., to produce biofuels) and disease treatment (e.g., for diabetes and cancer).

In the present grant, my lab developed analytical methods based on mass spectrometry that enable measurement of many metabolites at once. In addition, we innovated new ways of using stable isotope tracers to quantitate metabolic flows or “fluxes.” By providing a more global view of metabolic activity, these methods have proven a powerful tool for better understanding metabolism and its regulation. They are now used in dozens of labs, and have contributed to many important discoveries. For example, they facilitated the discovery of the oncometabolite 2-hydroxyglutarate, which is the underlying cause of about one-third of brain cancers and one-tenth of acute myeloid leukemia. Drugs to block 2-hydroxyglutarate production will soon enter clinical trials for the treatment of cancer.

An important application of these methods in my lab involved investigating metabolic regulation in the microorganisms E. coli and Bakers’ yeast. These microorganisms are important laboratory models for understanding of basic biochemistry and also are industrially important for production of chemicals and biofuels. We discovered a conserved response to nutrient deprivation across both of these organisms. An important aspect of this response was coordination of the metabolism of different nutrients – for example, when nitrogen is low, carbon metabolism also slows down. In E. coli, we proved that this coordination is carried out by the carbon substrate of nitrogen assimilation, ketoglutarate: When nitrogen is scarce relative to carbon, ketoglutarate rises, and this prevents further burning of carbon by blocking uptake of glucose. This discovery is important for understanding the fate of carbon in ecological situations when nitrogen is limiting, and also for metabolic engineering applications, when low nitrogen is often desired to prevent excessive microbial growth.

Beyond chemical tools and biochemical knowledge, future research into metabolism will also require well-trained scientists. To this end, I developed a new approach to teaching metabolism to undergraduates. The approach is grounded in organic chemistry and mathematics. Building from the basics of these fields, it strives to render metabolic pathways logical and intuitive, and thereby to avoid the requirement for rote memorization that previously drove most students away. The approach is been successful, in that many students trained my course of gone on to graduate study in fields involving metabolism, and that the course materials have been distributed to allow others to adapt aspects of this new approach.

Thus, through a combination of novel methodologies, important biological applications, and enhanced undergraduate education, this grant has contributed to the current renaissance metabolism and associated engineering and medical advances.
